Title: Prove the curvature of a level set equals divergence of the normalized gradient
Content:
Suppose we have a function $\phi : \mathbb{R}^2 	o \mathbb{R}$, and a curve $\gamma:\mathbb{R}	o\mathbb{R}^2$ defined by a level set of $\phi$, ie. the codomain of $\gamma$ is $\{(x,y)\mid\phi(x,y)=C\}$ for a given constant $C$. Edit: assume that $\gamma$ is parameterized by arc length, so $\left\|\gamma'(s)ight\|=1.$ The curvature of $\gamma$ is defined as $$\kappa(s)\equiv\left\|T'(s)ight\|=\left\|\gamma''(s)ight\|\,\,.$$ Show that it can also be written as
$$\kappa(s) = \left|
abla\cdot\left( rac{

abla\phiight|}ight)ight|$$

From $\| \gamma'(s) \| = 1$, it follows that $$0 =  rac{d}{ds} \langle \gamma'(s),\gamma'(s) angle = 2\langle \gamma''(s),\gamma'(s)angle.$$
So $\gamma'$ and $\gamma''$ are perpendicular. Assume that $\gamma''(s) 
eq 0$. Thus $N(s) := \gamma''(s)/\|\gamma''(s)\|$ locally defines a unit normal field to $\gamma$. Since $\gamma$ parametrizes a level set of $\phi$ and $
abla \phi$ is orthogonal to its level sets it follows that $
abla \phi / \|
abla \phi\|(\gamma(s)) = \pm N(s)$. Consequently 
$$\kappa(s) = \|\gamma''(s)\| = |\langle \gamma''(s),N(s)angle| = | rac{d}{ds} \langle \gamma'(s),N(s)angle - \langle \gamma'(s), rac{d}{ds}N(s)angle| = |\langle \gamma'(s), rac{d}{ds} N(s)angle|.$$
Since $\left\|N(s)ight\| = 1$ it follows as for $\gamma'$ that $\langle N, rac{dN}{ds} angle = 0$, thus $ rac{dN}{ds}$ is a multiple of $\gamma'$ and $\left\| rac{dN}{ds}ight\| = |\langle \gamma'(s), rac{dN}{ds}angle|$. Thus 
$$\kappa(s) = \left\| rac{dN}{ds}(s)ight\| = \left\| rac{d}{ds}  rac{
abla \phi}{\|
abla \phi\|}ight\|.$$
Thus it remains to see that $|
abla \cdot N| = \left\| rac{dN}{ds}ight\|$: For this one needs the following fact: Let $\{b_i\}$ be an orthonormal basis of $\mathbb R^n$. Then $$
abla \cdot X = \sum_{i = 1}^n \langle DX(b_i),b_iangle$$
for any vectorfield $X : \mathbb R^n 	o \mathbb R^n$ with differential $DX$. Unfortunately (via google) I did not find a reference for this Edit: Using Riemannian geometry this follows since divergence is defined as the trace of the Levi Civita connection $
abla$, which on $\mathbb R^n$ is given by $
abla_XY = DY(X)$ for vector fields $X,Y$. From this we see
$$\left\| rac{dN}{ds}(s)ight\| = \langle \gamma'(s), rac{dN}{ds}(s)angle = \langle \gamma'(s),DN(\gamma'(s))angle + \langle N(s),DN(N(s))angle = 
abla \cdot N(s).$$
By $DN$ we mean the differential of $N$ (note that strictly speaking this does not exists, as $N$ is only defined along $\gamma$. But we can extend $N$ to a vectorfield defined on an open subset using $N = \pm 
abla \phi/||
abla \phi||$ as above). The second equality holds since $\langle N,DN(X))angle = 1/2\partial_X\langle N,N angle = 0$ for any vector field $X$ ($\partial_X$ denotes the directional derivative in direction $X$). Maybe these calculations are more complicated than they could be, but I don't see a simplification right away.
